dictionary.title: Hormones_HumanHormones
dictionary.desc: Dictionary consisting of 84 terms plus 100 related synonyms. Some entries may also include the term's: source, description, wikidataID, chebiID, chebiName, FDAcode
dictionary.author: Emanuel Faria, ®Verriclear Natural Skin Essentials Ltd. https://www.verriclear.com
dictionary.contributor: Peter Murray-Rust: Reader Emeritus in Molecular Informatics, Unilever Centre, Dept. Of Chemistry University of Cambridge

entry.description: Hormone produced by Corticotrophs of the | Anterior pituitary lobe (adenohypophysis) Inhibits perception of pain
Hormone produced by P/D1 cells of the Stomach Stimulate appetite.
Hormone produced by ECL cells of the Stomach stimulate gastric acid secretion

Hormone produced by Sertoli cells of testes, granulosa cells of ovary; trophoblasts in fetus which Inhibit production of FSH; Produced byGranulosa cells of the Ovarian follicle and corpus luteum which Inhibit production of FSH from anterior pituitary; Produced by Fetal Trophoblasts of the Placenta (when pregnant) which Suppress FSH.
Hormone produced by of the Stomach Increased food intake and decreased physical activity. It can be associated with obesity.

Hormone produced by Chromaffin cells of the Adrenal medulla Fight-or-flight response: Boost the supply of oxygen and glucose to the brain and muscles (by increasing heart rate and stroke volume, vasodilation, increasing catalysis of glycogen in liver, breakdown of lipids in fat cells); Dilate the pupils; Suppress non-emergency bodily processes (e.g., digestion) blood pressure, glycogenolysis, lipolysis, etc.

Hormone produced by Chromaffin cells of the substantia nigra (mainly) of the Adrenal medulla, and the Dopamine neurons of the arcuate nucleus of they Hypothalamus. Increases heart rate and blood pressure. regulation of cellular cAMP levels, prolactin antagonist
Hormone produced by Pinealocytes of the Pineal body (epiphysis) Antioxidant; Monitors the circadian rhythm including induction of drowsiness and lowering of the core body temperature

Hormone produced by Chromaffin cells of the Adrenal medulla Fight-or-flight response: Boost the supply of oxygen and glucose to the brain and muscles (by increasing heart rate and stroke volume, vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure, breakdown of lipids in fat cells); Increase skeletal muscle readiness.

Hormone produced by Thyroid epithelial cells of the Thyroid Less active form of thyroid hormone. Acts as a prohormone to triiodothyronine. Stimulates body oxygen and energy consumption, thereby increasing the basal metabolic rate. Stimulates RNA polymerase I and II, thereby promoting protein synthesis

Hormone produced by Thyroid epithelial cell of the peripheral tissue of thyroid gland. More potent form of thyroid hormone. Stimulates body oxygen and energy consumption, thereby increasing the basal metabolic rate. Stimulates RNA polymerase I and II, thereby promoting protein synthesis
Produced by white blood cells of the Blood. Receptor: G protein-coupled receptors
Produced by endothelium. Receptor: prostacyclin receptor
Produced by seminal vesicle. Receptor: prostaglandin receptor
Hormone produced by Hepatocytes of the Liver stimulates megakaryocytes to produce platelets
Produced by adipose tissue. Receptor: adiponectin receptors
Produced by pancreatic β-cells of the pancreas. Receptor: amylin receptor
Hormone produced by Hepatocytes of the Liver vasoconstriction, release of aldosterone from adrenal cortex dipsogen.
Produced by Sertoli cell of the testes. Receptor: AMHR2

Hormone produced by Cardiac myocytes of the Heart. Reduces blood pressure by: increase sodium and GFR excretion, antagonize venal constriction, inhibit renin secretion, reducing systemic vascular resistance, reducing blood water, sodium and fats
Hormone produced by Cardiac myocytes of the Heart (To a lesser degree than ANP) reduce blood pressure by: reducing systemic vascular resistance, reducing blood water, sodium and fats
Hormone produced by Parafollicular cells of the Thyroid Stimulates osteoblasts and thus bone construction Inhibits Ca2+ release from bone, thereby reducing blood Ca2+
Hormone produced by I cells of the Duodenum Release of digestive enzymes from pancreas. Release of bile from gallbladder, hunger suppressant

Hormone produced by Corticotrophs of the | Anterior pituitary lobe (adenohypophysis) Stimulates corticosteroid (glucocorticoid and mineralcorticoid) and androgen synthesis and release from adrenocortical cells
Hormone produced by Parvocellular neurosecretory neurons of the Paraventricular nucleus of the Hypothalamus Stimulate adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) release from anterior pituitary
Produced by inhibitory neurons of the cerebral cortex. Receptor: Somatostatin receptor
Hormone produced by endothelial cells of the Stomach Smooth muscle contraction of medium-sized vessels of the stomach
Hormone produced by Chromaffin cells of the Adrenal medulla Regulate pain
Hormone produced by Extraglomerular mesangial cells of the Kidney Stimulate erythrocyte production

Hormone produced by Gonadotrophs of the | Anterior pituitary lobe (adenohypophysis) In females: Stimulates maturation of ovarian follicles in ovary; In males: Stimulates maturation of seminiferous tubules; In males: Stimulates spermatogenesis; In males: Stimulates production of androgen-binding protein from Sertoli cells of the testes
Produced by central nervous system and gastrointestinal tract. Receptor: GALR1, GALR2, and GALR3
Produced by K cell of the mucosa of the duodenum and the jejunum. Receptor: GIPR
Hormone produced by G cells of the Stomach and duodenum. Secretion of gastric acid by parietal cells
Hormone produced by α Islet cells of the Pancreas | Glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis in liver. Increases blood glucose level. |
Produced by L cells of the ileum. Receptor: GLP1R, GLP2R . Target Tissue: pancreatic beta cells

Hormone produced by Neuroendocrine cells of the Preoptic area of the Hypothalamus Stimulate follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) release from anterior pituitary; Stimulate luteinizing hormone (LH) release from anterior pituitary
Hormone produced by Neuroendocrine neurons of the Arcuate nucleus of the Hypothalamus Stimulate Growth hormone (GH) release from anterior pituitary
Produced by gut. Receptor: guanylate cyclase 2C (heat stable enterotoxin receptor)
Hormone produced by Hepatocytes of the Liver inhibits intestinal iron absorption and iron release by macrophages
Hormone produced by Syncytiotrophoblast cells of the Placenta (when pregnant) Promote maintenance of corpus luteum during beginning of pregnancy: Inhibit immune response, towards the human embryo.
Hormone produced by Syncytiotrophoblast of the Placenta (when pregnant) Increase production of insulin and IGF-1; Increase insulin resistance and carbohydrate intolerance

Hormone produced by β Islet cells (beta cells) of the Pancreas Intake of glucose, glycogenesis and glycolysis in liver and muscle from blood. Intake of lipids and synthesis of triglycerides in adipocytes. Other anabolic effects
Hormone produced by Hepatocytes of the Liver insulin-like effects. regulate cell growth and development
Hormone produced by Adipocytes of the Adipose tissue decrease of appetite and increase of metabolism
Produced by Corticotropes of the anterior pituitary.

Hormone produced by Gonadotrophs of the Anterior pituitary lobe (adenohypophysis) In females: Stimulates ovulation; In females: Stimulates formation of corpus luteum: In males: Stimulates testosterone synthesis from Leydig cells (interstitial cells)
Hormone produced by Melanotropes in the Pars intermedia of the Anterior pituitary lobe (adenohypophysis) Stimulates melanin synthesis and release from skin/hair melanocytes
Produced by Small intestine. Receptor: Motilin receptor
Produced by hypothalamus. Receptor: OX1, OX2
Hormone produced by osteoblasts of the Bone stimulates beta cells to produce insulin

Hormone produced by Magnocellular neurosecretory cells of the Posterior pituitary lobe (neurohypophysis) of the Hypothalamus. In females: uterine contraction during birthing, lactation (letdown reflex) when nursing
Hormone produced by PP cells of the Pancreas Self regulate the pancreas secretion activities and effect the hepatic glycogen levels.

Hormone produced by Parathyroid chief cell of the Parathyroid Calcium: Stimulates Ca2+ release from bone, thereby increasing blood Ca2+; Stimulates osteoclasts, thus breaking down bone; Stimulates Ca2+ reabsorption in kidney; Stimulates activated vitamin D production in kidney. Phosphate: Stimulates PO3−4 release from bones, thereby increasing blood PO3−4; Inhibits PO3−4 reabsorption in kidney, so more PO3−4 is excreted; Overall, small net drop in serum PO3−4.
Produced by multiple. Receptor: ADCYAP1R1, VIPR1, VIPR2
Decidual cells of uterus (when pregnant), Stimulates milk synthesis and release from mammary glands. Mediates sexual gratification |
Produced by hypothalamus.
Produced by seminal vesicle. Receptor: prostaglandin receptor
Hormone produced by Corpus luteum, Uterus, placenta, and Mammary gland (when pregnant).
Hormone produced by S cells of the Duodenum Secretion of bicarbonate from liver, pancreas and duodenal Brunner's glands. Enhances effects of cholecystokinin, stops production of gastric juice

Hormone produced by D cells (δ Islet cells) in the neuroendocrine neurons of the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus Somatostatin is classified as an inhibitory hormone, and is induced by low pH. Its actions are spread to different parts of the body. Somatostatin release is inhibited by the Vagus nerve.
Hormone produced by Somatotrophs of the | Anterior pituitary lobe (adenohypophysis) Stimulates growth and cell reproduction; Stimulates Insulin-like growth factor 1 release from liver
Hormone produced by liver, kidney, striated muscle. stimulates megakaryocytes to produce platelets
Produced by platelets of the Blood. Receptor: thromboxane receptor

Hormone produced by Thyrotrophs of the | Anterior pituitary lobe (adenohypophysis) Stimulates thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) synthesis and release from thyroid gland; Stimulates iodine absorption by thyroid gland
Produced by renal tissues. Receptor: guanylate cyclase 2C (heat stable enterotoxin receptor)
Produced by renal tissues. Receptor: guanylate cyclase 2C (heat stable enterotoxin receptor)

Hormone produced by Parvocellular neurosecretory neurons and Magnocellular neurosecretory neurons of the Paraventricular nucleus and Supraoptic nucleus of the Hypothalamus Increases water permeability in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct of nephrons, thus promoting water reabsorption and increasing blood volume

Hormone produced by Zona glomerulosa cells of the Adrenal cortex Stimulates active sodium reabsorption in kidneys; Stimulates passive water reabsorption in kidneys, thus increasing blood volume and blood pressure: Stimulates potassium and H+ secretion into nephron of kidney and subsequent excretion

Hormone produced by Zona glomerulosa cells of the Adrenal cortex Stimulates active sodium reabsorption in kidneys; Stimulates passive water reabsorption in kidneys, thus increasing blood volume and blood pressure: Stimulates potassium and H+ secretion into nephron of kidney and subsequent excretion
Hormone produced by Theca cells of the Ovarian follicle, adrenal glands, gonads and corpus luteum Substrate for estrogen
Produced by skin/proximal tubule of kidneys. Receptor: VDR
Hormone produced by skin/proximal tubule of kidneys. Active form of vitamin D3. Increase absorption of calcium and phosphate from gastrointestinal tract and kidneys inhibit release of PTH

Hormone produced by Keratinocytes of the Skin An inactive form of vitamin D3, Cholecalciferol is converted in the liver first to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcifediol) then to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), which is the hormonally active metabolite of vitamin D. Calcitriol increases the level of calcium (Ca2+) in the blood by increasing the uptake of calcium from the gut into the blood, increasing reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys, and possibly increasing the release of calcium into the blood from bone.
Produced by multiple cell types. Receptor: AR
Hormone produced by Granulosa cells, theca cells of the Ovarian follicle and corpus luteum in the Placenta (when pregnant)

Hormone produced by Leydig cells, Zona fasciculata and Zona reticularis cells of the Adrenal cortex Anabolic: growth of muscle mass and strength, increased bone density, growth and strength, Virilizing: maturation of sex organs, formation of scrotum, deepening of voice, growth of beard and axillary hair.

Hormone produced by Leydig cells, Zona fasciculata and Zona reticularis cells of the Adrenal cortex Anabolic: growth of muscle mass and strength, increased bone density, growth and strength, Virilizing: maturation of sex organs, formation of scrotum, deepening of voice, growth of beard and axillary hair.

Hormone produced by Leydig cells, Zona fasciculata and Zona reticularis cells of the Adrenal cortex Anabolic: growth of muscle mass and strength, increased bone density, growth and strength, Virilizing: maturation of sex organs, formation of scrotum, deepening of voice, growth of beard and axillary hair.
Hormone produced females: granulosa cells, males: Sertoli cell of the females: ovary, males testes. Prevent apoptosis of germ cells
Hormone produced by syncytiotrophoblast of the Placenta (when pregnant) Effects on mother similar to ovarian follicle estrogen

Hormone produced by Granulosa cells of the Ovarian follicle and corpus luteum Promote formation of female secondary sex characteristics; Accelerate height growth; Accelerate metabolism (burn fat); Reduce muscle mass; Stimulate endometrial growth; Increase uterine growth; Maintain blood vessels and skin; Reduce bone resorption, increase bone formation
Hormone produced by granulosa cells, Adipocytes of the ovary

Hormone produced by zona fasciculata and zona reticularis cells of the Adrenal cortex Stimulates gluconeogenesis: Stimulates fat breakdown in adipose tissue: Inhibits protein synthesis: Inhibits glucose uptake in muscle and adipose tissue: Inhibits immunological responses (immunosuppressive): Inhibits inflammatory responses (anti-inflammatory)

Hormone produced by zona fasciculata and zona reticularis cells of the Adrenal cortex Stimulates gluconeogenesis: Stimulates fat breakdown in adipose tissue: Inhibits protein synthesis: Inhibits glucose uptake in muscle and adipose tissue: Inhibits immunological responses (immunosuppressive): Inhibits inflammatory responses (anti-inflammatory)
